title: Hextech Repair Tool Re-Install?
body: Let's see, I got this software (also known as Hextech Repair Tool) to solve my lag from having 100-500 MS. What if I re-install league of legends? Will it take so long again like getting league for first time? Will it delete my account? Will it be like a fresh new league of legends player? I'm kinda getting too much on this which is making me feel if I should or not. Anyone?

replies.body: It says it will be a clean re-install. I don't know what it means by that.

It means that the client will be uninstalled then reinstalled completely and the client and game will have all default settings. A client repair won't always be able to fix all data errors every time, but a reinstall will. You won't lose any stats on your account or anything.

When you do a reinstall that is not 'clean' that typically means it will retain your personal settings folder and move it to the new install.
Is it worth it if I'm having 100-500 MS?

Repairing the client won't fix high latency issues. For that, please visit the [Connection Troubleshooting Guide](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/201752664-Troubleshooting-Connection-Issues). 

If you're not in NA it's expected to have high latency due to the distance to the servers, but otherwise if you can get a better connection you may be able to do so by switching to a wired connection and disabling background downloads while you play.

If you're having lag you can see where it starts by running a tracert to the NA servers. I suggest doing this by downloading the [WinMTR](http://winmtr.net/download-winmtr/) Network Diagnostic Tool and doing a traceroute to the below server IP for 5-15 minutes. It will show where your latency starts getting high to facilitate troubleshooting it;

> 104.160.131.1

For reference, you can run a tracert to the Google public DNS **8.8.8.8**. It should have about the best connection you can expect, so if the ping to Riot is significantly worse there may be an issue.
Ok, I downloaded the WinMTR, it's currently doing its work but I don't know what it's supposed to do.

It'll pump out numbers that look like this;

> |------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
|                                      WinMTR statistics                                   |
|                       Host              -   %  | Sent | Recv | Best | Avrg | Wrst | Last |
|------------------------------------------------|------|------|------|------|------|------|
|                             10.21.111.1 -    2 |   70 |   69 |   51 |   74 |  129 |   69 |
|                      temp1.unlinx.net -    2 |   70 |   69 |   31 |   77 |  129 |   65 |
|                           61.21.151.178 -    4 |   66 |   64 |   62 |   84 |  126 |   84 |
|                  v204.core2.mc2.he.net -    4 |   66 |   64 |   74 |  106 |  329 |   81 |
|              100ge8-1.core4.chf3.he.net -    2 |   70 |   69 |   80 |  108 |  330 |   98 |
|              100ge5-2.core2.chf3.he.net -    2 |   70 |   69 |   71 |   99 |  212 |  112 |
|                           104.160.131.1 -    2 |   70 |   69 |   68 |  107 |  214 |   89 |
|________________________________________________|______|______|______|______|______|______|
   WinMTR v0.92 GPL V2 by Appnor MSP - Fully Managed Hosting & Cloud Provider

(Stop, Copy text to clipboard, and paste)
The first column is the 'hops', the servers the data goes through to its destination. The first row of numbers would be at my house modem, and the last is the Riot server.

The second and third columns are how many packets of data are sent and received. Receiving less packets than it sent means there is some packet loss.

The columns after that are the ping in milliseconds (latency, ms). You can see the best (lowest) ping, average, worst (highest) and the last (current ping when you stopped it).

If you are getting packet loss or lag spikes you can see where along the route to the Riot servers it started; most of the time it starts at you and you have to fix something on your end, but it can also be at your ISP or at Riot or anywhere inbetween. Finding where it starts will allow you to start fixing it.
You can see extremely high ping spikes starting right from you. It could be background downloads, other people sharing your bandwidth on the same network, or just a really sketchy connection.
I don't know, It all started on Patch 6.14. Like I started having lag.

It looks like DTN was able to help you a bit here!  If you are still having issues, please reach out to us with a [player support ticket](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/requests/new).  We'd be happy to help out with your specific issue individually.  You can also attach the logs hextech repair tool provide into the ticket for context.  Thanks for your patience!
